value.0: <StartAction>[A floating skull hovers in the air before you, making the ultimate fate of the Maker readily apparent: he has become a demi-lich.]</Start>

<StartAction>[The skull turns its malevolent eyes in your direction and addresses you with a rasping voice you hear only in your head. The very words it speaks seem to twist and writhe within your mind.]</Start>
I do not recognize you as one of my creations. What manner of creature are you, that would invade my inner sanctum? Who are you, that dares to intrude upon my work?
<StartAction>[An angry roar of vile hatred echoes through your skull, and the demi-lich launches itself to attack.]</Start>
Once I was called Alsigard, known to many as the Maker. But now I have transcended the weakness of my flesh and body, and I am not what I once was.
I see you are a creature of <race> flesh. Not a construct, but an imperfect and flawed being. Flawed as all beings of substance must be... even my children.
Long ago I learned the weakness of the flesh. Friends and family will betray you, but the fault is not theirs. It is the weakness of the body that keeps them from perfection.
Once I understood this, I vowed to create a perfect being. A construct, built without weakness or flaw could do what an imperfect living creature could not. And so I created my golem children.
I began with mindless vessels, perfecting my technique. In time, I began to create golems with minds of their own; constructs with true free will. But even these creatures were imperfect.
Your impatience is a result of your imperfect flesh. You sense your own mortality, and you seek to accomplish as much as possible before your inevitable end.
But I have gone beyond such fears. Freed of my bodily existence, I at last approach true perfection. Now I will release you from the burden of your material body. I will set you free.
Precisely. My own body was flawed. It was weak, aging. How could an imperfect Maker create a perfect being?
The fault of my golems was actually mine. My own body was flawed. It was weak, aging. How could an imperfect Maker create a perfect being? My children were failures.
They had doubts and fears. They were afraid of change, afraid to evolve. The free will I had given them was a weakness, not a strength. Like all other beings, they were flawed.
I should have destroyed them. But I, too, was imperfect. Sentimental attachments clouded my thinking, and I allowed my children to live even as I retreated here in search of my own perfection.
I sealed myself here in my inner sanctum to continue my research without the distractions of an imperfect world. I realized the first step was to liberate my own consciousness from its flawed body.
Once I became a demi-lich much of what had clouded my thinking was stripped away. I had tried to make my golems into living creatures, but of course living creatures are themselves flawed.
At last I finally understood how to create a truly perfect being. For hundreds of years I have worked on this single creation, a golem unlike any other. And now, my work is all but complete.
You could not possibly understand the magnitude of what I am about to achieve. You are flawed, imperfect. You must be destroyed before your very presence here taints my experiment.
<StartAction>[The demi-lich shudders, and you hear it sigh within your mind.] </Start>This conversation is a waste of time; a sad remnant of the imperfect being I once was. There is no purpose here.
Perhaps. But they are still inherently flawed; I built them before I truly understood what had to be done. They will never achieve perfection, and they are therefore expendable.
Yeah, now you is nothing but floating skull. Deekin wonders: you floats all the time? Or maybe sometime you just roll around on floor likes a ball?
A kobold? I have not seen such a creature for many centuries. I cannot say I regret the absence of such beings. Kobolds are flawed, as all living creatures must be... even my children.
Die, foul creature!
Are you the Maker?
I'm going to destroy you!
Your children? You mean the golems?
What are you talking about?
I have to go.
I couldn't care less about this.
Maybe the problem was you.
How so?
And have you found perfection yet?
You abandoned the golems to become a demi-lich?
You're obviously insane.
What happens when you finish this perfect golem?
What still has to be done?
But your golems have evolved since you came down here.
My name is <FullName>.
